text:
The president of the International Paralympic Committee broke protocol in his speech at the opening ceremony of the Beijing Games on Friday, saying he was “horrified” by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

NYTIMES.COM
Paralympics President Rebukes Russia at Opening Ceremony

Russia’s war in Ukraine is not only reshaping the strategic and political order in Europe, it is also upending long-held assumptions about the intricate connections that are a signature of the global economy.

NYTIMES.COM
Economic Ties Among Nations Spur Peace. Or Do They?

“The only thing we hear is blasts, and it is nonstop.”

Mariupol, a key port city in southern Ukraine, has been under siege for days, leaving civilian areas burning and destroyed, according to video verified by The New York Times and interviews with residents.

NYTIMES.COM
‘The only thing we hear is blasts’: Residents said the port city of Mariupol is nearing a ‘humanitarian disaster.’

NATO officials on Friday accused Russia of using cluster bombs in its invasion of Ukraine but rejected Kyiv’s plea to impose a no-fly zone over Ukrainian airspace, fearing that would draw the military alliance into a larger war with Russia.

NYTIMES.COM
NATO Accuses Russia of Using Cluster Bombs in Ukraine

The Biden administration and European officials are aiming to devastate the Russian economy with sanctions to pressure President Vladimir Putin to end his war in Ukraine, contradicting earlier declarations by U.S. officials that they would refrain from inflicting pain on ordinary Russians.

NYTIMES.COM
With Sanctions, U.S. and Europe Aim to Punish Putin and Fuel Russian Unrest

Russia passed a law Friday punishing the spreading of "false information" about Russia’s forces with as much as 15 years in prison. The law could make a criminal offense of simply calling the war a "war" and will take effect as soon as Saturday.

NYTIMES.COM
Russia Steps Up Censorship With Law Against ‘False Information’

Facebook was blocked by the Russian government on Friday, as the Kremlin aims to limit spaces for dissent about the war in Ukraine. Instagram and WhatsApp, which are more popular than the Facebook app in Russia, are unaffected, the company said.

Follow live updates:

NYTIMES.COM
Ukraine Live Updates: Panic Grips Some Cities as Russia Tightens Cordon

The BBC said on Friday that it was temporarily suspending its operations in Russia after the country’s parliament passed a censorship law that penalizes anyone deemed to be “discrediting” the Russian military with 15 years in prison. It will still offer Russian-language news from outside Russia and its journalists in Ukraine will continue to report on the Russian invasion. https://nyti.ms/3hC9Ypx

NYTIMES.COM
BBC suspends its operations in Russia after strict censorship law is passed.
Shane Warne, one of the greatest cricket players of all time, and a larger-than-life figure on and off the field, died Friday in Thailand. He was 52. https://nyti.ms/3CfZNAt

Cultural institutions worldwide are grappling with whether to boycott Russian artists as the war in Ukraine continues. While attention has focused on those close to President Vladimir Putin, measures are also being taken against Russians with no apparent ties to him.

NYTIMES.COM
To Boycott Russians, or Not? In Film and Beyond, That’s the Question.

Senator Lindsey Graham on Thursday said somebody in Russia should “step up to the plate” and “take this guy out,” referring to President Vladimir Putin. Graham faced swift backlash from fellow Republicans.

NYTIMES.COM
Lindsey Graham says of Putin: Someone in Russia should ‘take this guy out.’

At least 57 people were killed and more than 100 wounded after an explosion tore through a Shiite mosque in Pakistan. The attack was most likely carried out by the region’s Islamic State affiliate, officials said. https://nyti.ms/3pChkO8

NATO foreign ministers rejected any possibility of intervening against Russian forces in Ukraine, whether on the ground or in the air, the alliance’s secretary general said Friday.

NYTIMES.COM
NATO rejects intervening in Ukraine, including with a no-fly zone.

Breaking News: The Russian government has blocked access to Facebook inside the country. It’s the latest instance of the Kremlin’s far-reaching campaign to clamp down on dissent in the wake of the invasion of Ukraine. https://nyti.ms/3hVSMf3

NYTIMES.COM
Ukraine Live Updates: Panic Grips Some Cities as Russia Tightens Cordon

Breaking News: A U.S. appeals court ruling barred the expulsion of migrant families on public health grounds if doing so would subject them to persecution.

NYTIMES.COM
An appeals ruling bars the U.S. from expelling any endangered migrant families on public health grounds.

The president of the International Paralympic Committee denounced Russia’s invasion of Ukraine during the opening ceremony of the Beijing Games on Friday, but Chinese social media users said the state-run broadcaster CCTV censored part of the speech.

NYTIMES.COM
Paralympics President Rebukes Russia at Opening Ceremony

The central train station in Kyiv unraveled into a scene of chaos on Friday as thousands of people, mostly women and children, raced to catch trains, fearing the window was closing to escape the city to the west. https://nyti.ms/35vQYGS

In The New York Times Opinion Section

Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s nomination fulfills President Biden’s promise to appoint a Black woman to the Supreme Court, Linda Greenhouse writes. “While that’s cause for celebration, it shouldn’t obscure the other kinds of diversity she would bring to the court.”

NYTIMES.COM
Opinion | Will Ketanji Brown Jackson Change the Way Any Other Supreme Court Justice Sees the World?

Princess Rita Boncompagni Ludovisi, a 72-year-old Texan, joined a decadent and dysfunctional aristocracy when she married a Roman prince. Now, in what she sees as betrayal in a noble family feud, she’s locked in a toxic inheritance battle over his estate.

NYTIMES.COM
In a Run-Down Roman Villa, a Princess From Texas Awaits Her Next Act

Mayor Eric Adams ended New York City’s mask mandate for public schools and a proof-of-vaccination requirement for indoor dining, gyms and entertainment venues. "It’s time to reopen our city," he said.

NYTIMES.COM
‘It’s time to reopen our city’: N.Y.C. mayor lifts a school mask mandate and indoor vaccination rules.

Good news for anyone frustrated by customer service chatbots: They are becoming less robotic, more conversational and more helpful.

NYTIMES.COM
Ending the Chatbot’s ‘Spiral of Misery’

In The New York Times Opinion Section

Jon Stewart believes a certain subset of the right has long viewed Vladimir Putin as “an ideological brother.” The former host of “The Daily Show” talks about Ukraine and misinformation with Kara Swisher on the latest episode of Sway.

NYTIMES.COM
Opinion | Jon Stewart on Why the Right Would ‘Rather Do a Deal With Putin Than Pelosi’

Breaking News: The Supreme Court reinstated the death sentence of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted of helping carry out the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings.

NYTIMES.COM
Supreme Court Restores Death Sentence for Boston Marathon Bomber

A fire set off by fighting at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant in Ukraine caused damage to a training facility about 1,500 feet from the nearest of the six reactors in the complex, an imagery analysis found.

See where it happened.

NYTIMES.COM
Maps: Tracking the Russian Invasion of Ukraine

Breaking News: Tesla won approval to begin production at its first major assembly plant in Europe, near Berlin. The company plans to build 500,000 electric cars a year there.

NYTIMES.COM
Tesla Wins Approval to Open European Assembly Plant

Brandon Sanderson, a sci-fi and fantasy author, started an online fund-raising campaign to self-publish four novels that he wrote during the pandemic. His goal: $1 million in 30 days.

He blew past the first million in about 35 minutes. In 24 hours, he raised $15.4 million.

NYTIMES.COM
Fantasy Author Raises $15.4 Million in 24 Hours to Self-Publish

The Texas primaries, the first elections of the 2022 midterms, showed the power of the once-in-a-decade redistricting process.

The Daily looks at the state’s transformed congressional map and speaks to Rep. Dan Crenshaw, a Republican. Listen to today’s episode.

NYTIMES.COM
The Death of the Competitive Congressional District

NATO rejected Ukraine’s pleas to establish a no-fly zone over the country, its secretary general said. The alliance has resisted such a move for fear that it could draw member states into the war. https://nyti.ms/3sG62KC

Fierce fighting in southeast Ukraine at Zaporizhzhia, Europe’s largest nuclear power plant, started a fire that was later extinguished, Ukrainian officials said, and there was no immediate sign that radiation had leaked. Russian troops have seized the complex.

Follow live updates. https://nyti.ms/34ebXxb

Black New Yorkers were hospitalized with Covid-19 at more than twice the rate of white New Yorkers during the recent Omicron wave, an indication that the health disparities seen during the pandemic are in some respects deepening, according to a new report.

NYTIMES.COM
During the Omicron surge, Black New Yorkers were hospitalized at a rate more than twice that of white residents.

Breaking News: Hiring in the U.S. sped up in February, with employers adding 678,000 jobs, as falling Covid cases brought customers and workers back.

NYTIMES.COM
February’s jobs report shows a gain of 678,000.

“If China wants to remain officially ambiguous about whether it supports Vladimir V. Putin’s war — refusing to call it an invasion and abstaining from a UN vote to condemn the invasion — its state-controlled media nonetheless makes very clear where China stands,” our columnist writes.

NYTIMES.COM
How China Embraces Russian Propaganda and Its Version of the War

Breaking News: At least 57 people were killed and more than 100 wounded after an explosion tore through a Shiite mosque in Pakistan. The attack was most likely carried out by the region’s Islamic State affiliate, officials said.

NYTIMES.COM
At Least 57 Dead in Pakistan After Mosque Attack

The UN Human Rights Council voted to set up a commission of inquiry to look into possible war crimes and human rights violations in Ukraine, adding impetus to global efforts to ensure Russia is held liable for its invasion and any abuses related to it.

Correction: An earlier version of this article said the UN Human Rights Council voted to set up an international tribunal. The council voted to set up a commission of inquiry, not an international tribunal.

NYTIMES.COM
The U.N. rights council will investigate possible war crimes in the Ukraine conflict.

Russian forces have seized the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, the largest in Europe. An earlier fire at the complex in Ukraine was extinguished, and there was no immediate sign of a radiation leak.

Follow live updates.

NYTIMES.COM
Ukraine Live Updates: Russians Seize Europe’s Largest Nuclear Plant, but Fire Is Out

Rashida Tlaib is the only Palestinian American serving in the House of Representatives, and the first to do so with family currently living in the West Bank.

She didn’t run for Congress with a plan to shift the Israeli-Palestinian debate and she is wary of adopting the role of the only Palestinian voice in the room. “I feel like no one wants to see me as anyone but Palestinian,” she told the New York Times Magazine.

“I’m a mother, I’m a woman, I have gone through a lot being the daughter of two immigrants in the United States. I’m also the big sister of 13 younger siblings. I’m also a neighbor in a predominantly Black city.”

NYTIMES.COM
What Rashida Tlaib Represents
Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has galvanized NATO’s 30 member states to assist “in one way or another,” Secretary of State Antony Blinken said at NATO headquarters on Friday. https://nyti.ms/3hDpj9n

Surprised by the speed at which sanctions have been poured on Russia, top U.S. officials are concerned that President Vladimir Putin’s reaction will be to double down and lash out — and perhaps expand the war beyond Ukraine.

NYTIMES.COM
Washington’s Newest Worry: The Dangers of Cornering Putin

A fire set off by a raging gun battle in southeast Ukraine at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant has been extinguished. Russian troops took control of the complex before dawn on Friday, Ukrainian officials said.

NYTIMES.COM
Fire at a Ukrainian nuclear plant is out, but Russian troops take control of the site.

Russia’s isolation is extending to space amid the fallout from the invasion of Ukraine. OneWeb, a British satellite maker, canceled launches that relied on the country, while the Russian space agency said it would stop selling rocket engines to U.S. companies.

NYTIMES.COM
Russia’s Isolation on Earth Moves Up Into Space

The Ukrainian Navy purposely sank the flagship of its Black Sea fleet on Thursday to prevent the warship from being seized by the Russian military, Ukraine’s defense minister said.

NYTIMES.COM
Ukraine’s Navy says it purposely sank its flagship Black Sea vessel.

It could be harder to get into one of California’s most prestigious universities after the state’s highest court declined to reverse a lower-court ruling that capped enrollment at the University of California, Berkeley, at 2020-21 levels.

NYTIMES.COM
U.C. Berkeley Must Freeze Enrollment, California Supreme Court Says

Dear Wirecutter,

My dog refuses to go outside in any kind of bad weather, and I hate dragging her down my front steps by her leash. Is there a kinder and gentler way to get my mutt to go for a walk on rainy or snowy days?

NYTIMES.COM
Ask Wirecutter: How Can I Convince My Prima Donna Pooch to Go Outside in Bad Weather?

Russian troops in southeast Ukraine seized the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, the largest in Europe, Ukrainian officials said, hours after a large fire broke out at the complex during the assault. There was no sign that radiation had leaked, international monitors said.

Follow our live updates. https://nyti.ms/3Mir2iF

Scientists say humans are speeding extinction at a disastrous pace. Their work to protect biodiversity is critical, and maps like these offer a valuable tool to officials and conservationists.

See where land is permanently protected for biodiversity.

NYTIMES.COM
This Map Shows Where Biodiversity Is Most at Risk in America

No matter how stocked your vacation rental may be, here are five items Wirecutter suggests you bring with you, just in case. https://nyti.ms/35J9D1E

NYTIMES.COM
5 Cheap(ish) Things to Bring to a Vacation Rental

Many African leaders are sitting out the global outcry over Russia's invasion of Ukraine, reluctant to criticize a country that supported their liberation struggles and is still a source of trade, education and arms

NYTIMES.COM
Shunned by Others, Russia Finds Friends in Africa

Ukraine accused Russia of deliberately firing on the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant. Officials later said the blaze had been put out, and that there was no indication of a rise in radiation levels.

Follow live updates.

NYTIMES.COM
Live Updates: Russians Seize Europe’s Largest Nuclear Plant, Ukrainian Officials Say

“El Carnaval es una manifestación cultural, no un evento,” dijo Rafael Comote, un trompetista de 30 años que llevaba una peluca rosa y un chaleco prestado del Departamento de Salud de Río. “El Carnaval no es algo que se pueda prohibir.”

“The Carnival is a cultural demonstration, not an event,” said Rafael Comote, a 30-year-old trumpet player wearing a pink wig and a vest borrowed from the Rio Department of Health. “Carnival is not something that can be banned. "

NYTIMES.COM
Con mallas y purpurina, los músicos de Río tenían una misión: salvar el Carnaval

In The New York Times Opinion Section: “At a time when our society is deeply divided,” Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Andrew Curran write, “it feels urgent that we develop new language for discussing the relationship between identity, ancestry, history and science.”

NYTIMES.COM
Opinion | We Need a New Language for Talking About Race

Jessica Cisneros was an intern for Representative Henry Cuellar not too long ago. Now, with the backing of national progressive leaders, she has forced the nine-term Democratic congressman from Texas into a runoff.

NYTIMES.COM
The Young Progressive Lawyer at the Center of a Marquee Texas Runoff

Two Russian nationals flying in a private jet that had taken off from Geneva landed in Canada this week and were stopped from traveling farther, Canadian officials said.

Canada had announced on Sunday that it would ban Russian aircraft from its airspace.

NYTIMES.COM
Two Russian nationals flew into Canada and were stopped, officials said.

“Do people actually care if you’re sorry or not?” Listen to Anna Sorokin, the con artist once known as Ana Delvey, who inspired a Netflix series, talk to our reporter Emily Palmer about remorse. https://nyti.ms/3tpZAqt

Russian forces are attacking Ukraine on a number of fronts, with the main focus on capturing the capital, Kyiv.

These maps track where Russia has made advances and attacked.

NYTIMES.COM
Maps: Tracking the Russian Invasion of Ukraine

Ukrainian troops are fighting with a resourcefulness and creativity that U.S. analysts said could trip up Russian troops for weeks or months to come.

NYTIMES.COM
How Ukraine’s Military Has Resisted Russia So Far

Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain said he would seek an emergency meeting of the UN Security Council on the situation at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear complex in Ukraine, a statement from his office said.

Follow live updates.

NYTIMES.COM
Live Ukraine Updates: Fire Breaks Out at Europe’s Largest Nuclear Complex During Attack

Videos verified by The New York Times reveal the scale of the devastation of civilian areas in Kharkiv, Ukraine, after days of Russian bombardment.

NYTIMES.COM
Videos show widespread destruction in civilian areas of Kharkiv.

Farrah Forke, who catapulted to fame playing the helicopter pilot Alex Lambert on the NBC sitcom “Wings,” has died at 54.

NYTIMES.COM
Farrah Forke, Who Played a Helicopter Pilot on ‘Wings,’ Dies at 54

The Justice Department is facing mounting pressure to prosecute Donald Trump after the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack laid out its argument for a potential criminal case.

NYTIMES.COM
Pressure on Justice Dept. as Jan. 6 Panel Lays Out Case Against Trump

Google said that it had suspended all advertising in Russia after the country’s internet regulator demanded that the company stop showing what it considered ads displaying false information about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

NYTIMES.COM
Google Suspends Advertising in Russia

Lukoil, Russia’s second-largest oil company, appeared to distance itself from President Vladimir Putin on Thursday by calling for a “fast resolution” to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

NYTIMES.COM
Lukoil, a Russian Oil Company, Calls for an End to the Ukraine War

A former Fox News producer was charged with violating U.S. sanctions by working for a Russian oligarch who has been accused of being a leading financial supporter of separatists in Crimea and Ukraine and has close ties to President Vladimir Putin.

NYTIMES.COM
Ex-Fox News Producer Broke Law With Work for Russian Oligarch, U.S. Says

In a legal filing, the Jan. 6 panel laid out a narrative aimed at showing that Donald Trump knew the 2020 election was not stolen and sought to overturn it anyway.

NYTIMES.COM
Panel Suggests Trump Knew He Lost the Election, Eyeing Criminal Case

Breaking News: The Florida Legislature voted to ban most abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy. Gov. Ron DeSantis has signaled his support for the bill.

Read more: https://nyti.ms/3trMLMq

Breaking News: The Florida Legislature voted to ban most abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy. Gov. Ron DeSantis has signaled his support for the bill.

NYTIMES.COM
Florida Lawmakers Vote to Ban Abortions After 15 Weeks

A 19-year-old testified against his father in a trial related to the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol. “He said, ‘If you turn me in, you’re a traitor,’” Jackson Reffitt told the jury as his father watched him intently from across the courtroom and then looked down. “‘And traitors get shot.’”

NYTIMES.COM
‘Traitors Get Shot’: Son Testifies Against Father in Jan. 6 Trial

The Biden administration announced it would offer humanitarian relief to Ukrainians who have been living in the country without legal documentation since March 1 or earlier, signaling additional support for citizens of Ukraine.

NYTIMES.COM
U.S. Grants Temporary Protected Status to Some Ukrainians

A fire broke out at a complex in Ukraine that is home to Europe’s largest nuclear power plant, after Russian troops fired on the area, Ukraine’s foreign minister said. Security camera footage verified by The New York Times showed a building ablaze inside the power complex near a line of military vehicles.

Follow our live updates.

NYTIMES.COM
Fire breaks out at nuclear complex, Ukraine says, as Russian forces move through.

A Florida fund-raiser planned for April that was to feature Melania Trump has been called off after state regulators there concluded that the company working with the former first lady to organize the charitable event had not properly registered to solicit contributions.

NYTIMES.COM
Melania Trump Event Called Off After Officials Question Fund-Raising

“We have a special people, an extraordinary people,” President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said at his first news conference since the war began. Zelensky, whose defiance has made him a symbol of Ukrainian resistance to the Russian invasion, laid out the state of negotiations with Russia, voiced pride in his people, pleaded for a no-fly zone and spoke frankly about fear of dying.

NYTIMES.COM
Behind Sandbags, Ukraine’s Leader Meets the Media

Ukrainians fleeing Russia’s invasion of their country will be offered temporary protection in the European Union, its ministers decided on Thursday, as the exodus from Ukraine surpassed a million people. The UN predicted that 10 million Ukrainians — roughly a quarter of the population — could be displaced.

Read more: https://nyti.ms/3Kg7vxu

More than two million Ukrainians have fled the country or been displaced, according to the UN. They are fleeing not only physical danger but also the desperation of wartime conditions: food shortages, loss of work and a dearth of medical supplies.

“When I got in the car I started crying,” said a 19-year-old woman staying at a two-room kindergarten in Viitivtsi, in western Ukraine. “I just started to cry because I realized I am leaving my country and running from a war. It’s an awful feeling.”

NYTIMES.COM
On the Exodus West, Ukrainians Flee Hardship for an Uncertain Future

We spent a night at Milan Fashion Week with Julia Fox.

NYTIMES.COM
Julia Fox Will Come for You

Travelers arriving at Perth Airport in the state of Western Australia reunited with their loved ones for the first time in two years after the region lifted the remaining pandemic-era border restrictions for vaccinated travelers.

Read more: https://nyti.ms/3IM3y35

Medical students at a university in Sumy, Ukraine, saw their school become a war zone overnight. They have no way to travel home and are hoping that authorities can create a safe corridor for them to evacuate. “I wake up, I’m just thinking, how am I going to get out of here?” one student said.

Read more: https://nyti.ms/3Kcf5ZV

Breaking News: The Biden administration is offering temporary protected status to Ukrainians who were living in the U.S. without documentation as of March 1.

NYTIMES.COM
U.S. will allow some Ukrainians to stay in the country temporarily.

More than 800 medical students are stranded at their university in the city of Sumy in northeastern Ukraine, officials said, after Russian forces hindered access to roads and trains. The students are mostly from African countries and India.

"We don’t really have proper food," said Michael, a third-year medical student from Ghana. "I'm basically eating biscuits."

NYTIMES.COM
More than 800 medical students, most African or Indian, are stranded in northeastern Ukraine.

Viral stories like the Ghost of Kyiv — a Ukrainian pilot who supposedly single-handedly shot down several Russian fighter jets — are of questionable veracity. But they're a key part of Ukraine's war plan, experts say, as it tries to keep morale high.

NYTIMES.COM
Fact and Mythmaking Blend in Ukraine’s Information War

“There is a real war raging here. I’m afraid.”
“Mama, this is so hard.”

Text messages purporting to be from a Russian soldier to his mother, read publicly this week by Ukraine’s UN ambassador, underscore the contest underway to shape the war’s narrative.

NYTIMES.COM
An information battle over Ukraine takes center stage.

An unidentified woman's dismembered torso was found stuffed in a shopping cart in Brooklyn early Thursday. The grisly discovery was made in a large bag that was inside the cart, the police said.

NYTIMES.COM
Woman’s Dismembered Body Is Found in Shopping Cart in Brooklyn

“Lupin,” Netflix’s French heist drama, was itself at the center of a heist last week: About 20 young men stole equipment valued at more than $300,000 from the set during filming in a Paris suburb, a company spokeswoman said.

NYTIMES.COM
‘Lupin,’ Netflix’s French Heist Drama, Is the Victim of a Theft

The Biden administration asked Congress to provide $32.5 billion in emergency aid on Wednesday, seeking to bolster the domestic response to the coronavirus pandemic, and support Ukraine in its fight against Russia's invasion.

NYTIMES.COM
The Biden administration asks Congress for $22.5 billion to bolster the Covid response.

France will no longer require visitors to show proof of a Covid vaccine to enter indoor establishments after March 14, officials announced on Thursday, most likely clearing the way for Novak Djokovic to play at the French Open this spring.

NYTIMES.COM
A Covid ruling has opened the French Open door to Novak Djokovic.

A ragtag group of revelers convened near a popular plaza in Rio de Janeiro recently to break the rules and start a party. In their view, they were there to save Carnival, which had been effectively canceled for the second consecutive year.

NYTIMES.COM
In Glitter and Leotards, They Took a Stand: Carnival Must Go On

President Vladimir Putin for the first time personally acknowledged Russian losses in the war in Ukraine in a video televised on Russian state media on Thursday. He also claimed the military operation was proceeding according to plan.

Follow live updates: https://nyti.ms/3Cj8SbN

Flag manufacturers across the U.S. are cutting and sewing blue and yellow fabric as fast as possible to keep up with the surge in demand for the flag of Ukraine since the country was invaded by Russia last week.

“This would be the biggest increase in volume for another nation’s flag that I’ve ever seen,” said Artie Schaller III, president of the National Flag Company. “I can only compare it to — in my time — to 9/11, for just how quickly people are willing to show support and are using a flag to do that.”

NYTIMES.COM
U.S. flag makers are rushing to fill orders for Ukrainian flags.

At least 10 people were injured, several of them seriously, in an explosion and fire that destroyed most of an apartment building in Silver Spring, Maryland, Thursday morning, fire officials said. https://nyti.ms/3pwnMpW

Ikea and TJX, the owner of TJ Maxx and Marshalls, became the latest retailers to halt business operations in Russia, joining the growing number of Western companies condemning the country’s invasion of Ukraine.
https://nyti.ms/3Kev61r

NYTIMES.COM
Ikea and the owner of T.J. Maxx are the latest retailers to halt Russia operations.

At least 10 people were injured, several of them seriously, in an explosion and fire that destroyed most of an apartment building in Silver Spring, Maryland, on Thursday, fire officials said.

NYTIMES.COM
At Least 10 Are Injured in Explosion at Maryland Apartment Building

Russia and Ukraine concluded a second round of talks in Belarus, emerging with little progress but agreeing to deliver food and medicine to areas of Ukraine where fighting is intense and to establish "humanitarian corridors" with the possibility of cease-fires to enable civilians to use them.

NYTIMES.COM
Live Updates: 1 Million Have Fled Ukraine; Russia Bombards Key Cities

Breaking News: The NFL has suspended all Covid protocols, becoming the first major American sports league to do so.

NYTIMES.COM
N.F.L. Becomes First Major American Sports League to Drop Covid-19 Protocols
Breaking News: Brett Hankison, the only officer charged in the fatal police raid on Breonna Taylor’s apartment, was found not guilty of endangering her neighbors. https://nyti.ms/3CccQD4
Hundreds of people waited in long lines for food in Kharkiv as Ukraine warned of a humanitarian crisis caused by Russia’s invasion. https://nyti.ms/3IFfcgg

One million Ukrainians have become refugees in the week since Russian forces invaded, the UN said, and another million people have been displaced or are on the move inside the country. https://nyti.ms/3trQtFJ

Rural parts of the U.S. have fallen even further behind in vaccinating people against Covid-19 since all adults became eligible for vaccines, making reducing death tolls in those areas difficult, the CDC said.

NYTIMES.COM
Rural areas in the U.S. fall further behind in vaccination rates, the C.D.C. reports.

The U.S., Europe and its allies are not launching missiles or sending troops to push back against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, so they have weaponized the most powerful nonmilitary tool they have available: the global financial system.

NYTIMES.COM
Russia Tried to Isolate Itself, but Financial Ties Called Its Bluff

Russian operations in northern Ukraine appeared to be stalled for a third day as the Kremlin sent more troops into the country, a senior defense official said Thursday morning, adding that Ukrainian forces may be attacking a convoy of Russian forces attempting to take the major northern cities of Kyiv, Chernihiv and Kharkiv.

NYTIMES.COM
The Pentagon says Russian forces remain stalled in Ukraine’s north.

Though Roman Abramovich is trying to sell the English soccer team Chelsea for what is said to be at least $2.5 billion, the price he and other Russian oligarchs will get for their assets remains unclear.

NYTIMES.COM
International pressure is forcing Russian oligarchs to sell their assets. But who’s buying?

The International Chess Federation is working to distance itself from Russia, canceling tournaments and disqualifying grandmasters who support the invasion of Ukraine.

NYTIMES.COM
Ukraine War Disrupts the Quiet World of Chess

President Vladimir Putin for the first time personally acknowledged Russian losses in the war in Ukraine in televised remarks on Thursday, and tried to counter assessments from Western officials that Russia was running into more resistance than expected.

NYTIMES.COM
Live Updates: 1 Million Have Fled Ukraine; Russia Bombards Key Cities

A phone conversation between President Emmanuel Macron and President Vladimir Putin on Thursday offered little hope that the fighting in Ukraine would abate soon.

The Kremlin said it had no intention of backing down from a war that "is going according to plan," and a senior official in the French presidency warned that Putin appeared determined to invade the whole country.

NYTIMES.COM
A Putin-Macron call leaves France persuaded that Russia wants ‘control of all of Ukraine.’

Breaking News: The Sackler family and Purdue Pharma reached a deal with a group of U.S. states to settle thousands of opioid lawsuits.

NYTIMES.COM
Sacklers and Purdue Pharma Reach New Deal With States Over Opioids

Video verified by The New York Times shows the bombardment of Chernihiv, a key city on Russia's path toward Kyiv, on Thursday. The attack hit near apartment buildings, pharmacies and a hospital — as the smoke clears, people are seen running in the street. https://nyti.ms/3HGnzqi

Breaking News: The Russian soprano Anna Netrebko won’t sing at the Metropolitan Opera for at least two seasons after the company demanded she distance herself from Vladimir Putin.

NYTIMES.COM
Anna Netrebko, Russian Diva, Is Out at the Metropolitan Opera

Russian forces are ramping up assaults on civilian areas of Ukraine a week after invading the country. As Russia begins laying siege to major Ukrainian cities, the war is entering an increasingly brutal phase.

NYTIMES.COM
One Week After Russia’s Invasion, Here’s How the War Is Evolving

Ukrainians are facing a deepening humanitarian crisis as Russian forces bombard urban areas, reducing basic services to rubble.

A million people have become refugees in the past week, the UN said, as packed evacuation trains carry them west. https://nyti.ms/3MjOMCT

The U.S. surgeon general formally requested that big tech platforms provide information about the scale of Covid misinformation on their sites.

The notice asked for details of “exactly how many users saw or may have been exposed to” Covid misinformation.

NYTIMES.COM
The surgeon general calls on Big Tech to turn over Covid-19 misinformation data.

Russian soldiers destroyed bridges and obstructed the food supply in the southern Ukrainian city of Mariupol, its mayor said. He described “a blockade” that has prevented residents from evacuating.

Before dawn broke in Ukraine on Thursday, Russian forces began to invade the nation through northern forests, eastern plains and along the southern coast, igniting battles around the country that left dozens dead and drew new sanctions that President Biden said would buckle Russia’s economy.

By sunset, special forces and airborne troops were closing in on Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv. Thousands of Ukrainian civilians fled imperiled cities, and thousands of Russians protested the decision to go to war. President Vladimir Putin remained defiant as Ukrainians, Russians and observers around the world took stock of the day’s toll. Here are some of the day’s major events:

After a battle in the highly radioactive grounds of the Chernobyl exclusion zone, Russian forces seized the power plant where a nuclear reactor melted down in 1986. The condition of the concrete-encased reactor was unknown.

President Biden said new sanctions would target Russia’s elites, top banks and technology exports. He said that the U.S. military would not fight in Ukraine, but that troops would be deployed to NATO’s eastern flank.

At least 40 Ukrainian soldiers were killed, officials said, adding that Ukraine had destroyed two Russian helicopters and seven aircraft. The Russian Defense Ministry said its forces had destroyed more than 70 military targets, including 11 airfields, a helicopter and four drones.

Thousands of Russians protested the invasion, and hundreds were detained, according to a group that tallies arrests. Putin, speaking to businessmen on a day when the Russian stock market lost one-third of its value, defended his attack on Ukraine as a “necessary measure.”

The Russian invasion of Ukraine is threatening to cut off some international shipments of wheat. Russia and Ukraine together produce nearly a quarter of the world’s wheat, feeding billions of people.

Brandon Smith, a fourth generation Texas cattle rancher and father of four, was relieved when President Biden signed a $1.9 trillion stimulus package into law nearly a year ago, because it included $4 billion of debt forgiveness for Black farmers. Smith, who owes $200,000 in outstanding loans on his ranch, quickly signed and returned the documents to formally accept the debt relief. He then purchased more equipment for his ranch, believing that he had been given a financial lifeline.

Instead, over a year later, Smith has fallen deeper into debt. He received a notice informing him that the federal government intended to “accelerate” foreclosure on his 46-acre property if he did not start making payments on the loans he believed had been forgiven.

Smith is one of many Black farmers across the nation — a group that has endured decades of discrimination from banks and the federal government — who have yet to see any of President Biden's promised relief because the initiative has been held up by lawsuits from white farmers alleging reverse discrimination.

https://nyti.ms/3H9LChm

“I’m working in the United States while my parents live abroad. My father made an unfortunate investment decision a couple of years ago, lost almost all his money and has been in debt ever since. I helped him pay off some of his debts, but recently I have been hesitating to send more money.

“I have managed to save some money myself, but it’s far from enough to pay his debts. Plus, I’m here in this country alone, and I want to have some savings. I also fear that if he develops a habit of relying on me, he will stop trying to find a way to earn money or to collect from people who owe him money.

“However, my dad has been trying to solve this situation for some time and has made little progress. It really hurts to see him so sad. I’m worried that if things continue this way for a few years, it will take a toll on his mental and physical health.

“Am I coldhearted not to help my dad financially? Should I give him more money, or even all my money? I am not a spendthrift, for sure, but I haven’t been frugal either, and I sometimes feel guilty because I think maybe I should have been.”

How Much Help Do I Owe My Debt-Ridden Dad?

The image stopped him cold. Josh Koskoff, a Connecticut lawyer, was scanning crime scene photos of the 2012 Sandy Hook school shooting when he noticed two ammunition magazines crudely duct-taped together to speed reloading on a classroom floor.

The gunman had dropped them during his rampage that killed 20 first graders and six educators in Newtown, Connecticut.

That photo was a “checkmate moment,” Koskoff said, in the novel legal strategy that ultimately resulted in the $73 million settlement last week for the families of nine Sandy Hook victims from insurers for the Remington, the maker of rifle used in the massacre. It was the largest payout so far in a mass-shooting-related case against a gun manufacturer.

Devastated when Congress didn't pass gun control legislation after the 2012 Sandy Hook shooting, the families have now won on two difficult fronts — against a gun manufacturer and against conspiracy theorists, including Alex Jones — through persistence, creative legal strategies and tech expertise.

NYTIMES.COM
How They Did It: Sandy Hook Families Savor Long-Awaited Legal Wins

In 2020 alone, Northwest Texas Hospital in Amarillo, Texas lost 185 nurses — nearly 20% of its nursing staff. In the ICU, that number was closer to 80%. Many of those nurses left to take jobs with travel-nursing agencies, which placed them, on a temporary and highly lucrative basis, in hospitals throughout the country.

Bedside nursing has always been, as one hospital chief executive put it, a ‘‘burnout profession.’’ The work is hard. It is physical and emotional. And hospitals have built shortages into their business model. But when the pandemic hit, shortages only increased, pushing hospitals to the breaking point. Nationwide, the tally of nurses with both the skills and the willingness to endure the punishing routines of Covid nursing — the isolation rooms, the angry families and the unceasing drumbeat of death — is dwindling. In a survey of critical-care nurses last year, 66 percent of respondents said they were considering retirement.

NYTIMES.COM
‘Nurses Have Finally Learned What They’re Worth’

Flight attendants have described passengers hitting them, kicking seats and throwing trash at them. One man argued with attendants who told his son to stop vaping. As he was escorted off the plane, he yelled at a flight attendant, ‘‘Imagine all of you in body bags.’’ Another man dumped a diaper filled with poop in the beverage cart, ending service for the rest of the flight.

Pandemic anxiety, hostility and tantrums have turned airplanes into battlefronts for flight attendants. People are angry about wearing masks. People are angry at those who don’t wear masks. They are all tired of the long lines, packed airplanes and cancellations caused by weather and Omicron. And if a customer spins out of control, flight attendants have no escape and no way to eject the passenger.

The public thinks ‘‘we are nothing more than cocktail waitresses,’’ one said.

See (the Worst People in) the World!

Mayor Eric Adams and Gov. Kathy Hochul announced on Friday that they would no longer allow the city’s subway system to be used for anything but transportation. They are responding to an increase in crime in New York City subways and concerns from riders about harassment by people who shelter on trains.

The New York Police Department will now stringently enforce the subway’s often flouted rules of conduct, they said. Open drug use and smoking will no longer be tolerated. Any rider found sprawled across subway seats will be escorted off the train and offered help.

The new effort, which was detailed in a document released Friday called The Subway Safety Plan, will go into effect next week, Adams said. The plan also contains measures aimed at connecting people who shelter in the subways to services and permanent housing.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the safety plan. Photo by @hlswift taken during the MTA’s subway closures in 2020.

In late January, Tiffany Dyba, a 39-year-old recruiter working on contract with a tech company on the West Coast, sent out a mass blast on LinkedIn, tailored to reach data analysts. “Hi [name],” Dyba wrote in the message. “We’re looking for a talented Data Analyst to analyze huge data sets, build predictive models, and help us drive growth. I thought you could be a great fit.” The job she posted listed its selling points — the business had 400 percent growth a year, the backing of a legendary venture capitalist, no limit to personal vacation days, full coverage of employee health-care premiums and the option to work remote or locally.

Dyba estimates that she sent the listing to about 75 prospective hires and received back maybe five responses, three of which were either a brief “no thanks” or the simple declination of her InMail message.

Recruiters working in technology these days do not receive candy, flowers or thank-yous. The recruiter is lucky if she can get someone on the phone — if she receives so much as an email in response. Technology workers need court no one: Along with microchips, toilet paper and Covid tests, tech workers will be recalled as one of the great, pressing shortages of this pandemic.

NYTIMES.COM
Tech Companies Face a Fresh Crisis: Hiring

As r/antiwork grew, the community wasn’t just complaining about mean bosses. At least as much energy seemed to be devoted to discussions about improving pay and working conditions. Plans for protests would be made on Antiwork; then, three days later, they could be seen taking place on YouTube. The percentage of employed people who quit their jobs had increased sharply in the summer of 2020, but by the fall the quit rate was higher than it had been in two decades. It kept rising in 2021, and by the end of last summer it reached 3 percent. In May 2021, Anthony Klotz, a professor at Mays Business School, coined a term for this trend: the Great Resignation. In the antiwork subreddit, it seemed that a force was emerging — a community of people, mainly low-wage and blue-collar workers, fed up with their working conditions.

NYTIMES.COM
Hating Your Job Is Cool. But Is It a Labor Movement?

It’s true that we’re in the midst of a “quitagion,” given the record number of people (4.5 million) who gave notice in November alone. An estimated 25 million people left their jobs in the second half of 2021. But those top-line numbers obscure a muddier truth. After the latest employment numbers were released in February, they seemed to show remarkable job growth and an unemployment rate of 4 percent. In addition to those workers trying to trade their way into objectively better jobs, millions of others have simply left the work force — because they’re sick, or taking care of children, or retiring, or just plain miserable.

Even among the people who were technically employed, a sizable number were unable to work because of child care issues or sick leave. Add to that the fact that many people who would prefer full-time work with benefits are still working on employers’ terms, which means part-time, unstable employment And if you dig into the quit numbers for higher-wage workers, it’s still hardly about people going on “Eat, Pray, Love” journeys. The full picture just isn’t that rosy, as Noreen Malone writes in the New York Times Magazine.

NYTIMES.COM
The Age of Anti-Ambition

In 2020 alone, Northwest Texas Hospital in Amarillo, Texas lost 185 nurses — nearly 20% of its nursing staff. In the ICU, that number was closer to 80%. Many of those nurses left to take jobs with travel-nursing agencies, which placed them, on a temporary and highly lucrative basis, in hospitals throughout the country.

Bedside nursing has always been, as one hospital chief executive put it, a ‘‘burnout profession.’’ The work is hard. It is physical and emotional. And hospitals have built shortages into their business model. But when the pandemic hit, shortages only increased, pushing hospitals to the breaking point. Nationwide, the tally of nurses with both the skills and the willingness to endure the punishing routines of Covid nursing — the isolation rooms, the angry families and the unceasing drumbeat of death — is dwindling. In a survey of critical-care nurses last year, 66 percent of respondents said they were considering retirement.

NYTIMES.COM
‘Nurses Have Finally Learned What They’re Worth’

"My husband and I employ a wonderful young woman to care for our two children after school. They love her dearly, and we feel incredibly lucky to have her, except for one thing: She is unvaccinated. We've been slow to confront the situation, but with Omicron spreading widely in our community, we're torn about whether we can continue to allow her to work for us.

"Our after-school babysitter comes from a minority community with an understandably low trust in government and the medical profession. Her community has been skeptical of the vaccine and has one of the lowest vaccination rates in our city. Over time, her family has been vaccinated. But she has been influenced by online misinformation about the vaccine's impact on fertility and possible allergic reactions.

"Rapid tests are free and easily available here, so she has been testing twice weekly. But the risk calculus feels like it has changed due to the infectiousness of Omicron. Still, we are heartsick about the idea of firing her. And firing someone because they make a choice about their personal medical care feels like an expression of white supremacy, even if this choice affects us. Never mind that vaccines are less protective against Omicron and so less effective in stopping the virus's spread.

"My head is telling me that we must tell her we don't feel comfortable allowing someone who is unvaccinated to care for our children, but my heart is troubled."

NYTIMES.COM
Should We Fire Our Unvaccinated Babysitter?

Everyone can feel worthy.” https://nyti.ms/3sIlPay

Dennis Hope has spent 27 years in solitary confinement in a Texas prison, in a cell that is 9 feet long and 6 feet wide — smaller than a compact parking space.

His only human contact is with the guards who strip-search and handcuff him before taking him to another enclosure to exercise, alone. He has had one personal phone call since 1994, when his mother died in 2013. He suffers from depression and paranoia and fears he is going insane.

Last month, Hope asked the Supreme Court to consider setting limits on prolonged isolation under the Eighth Amendment, which bars cruel and unusual punishments.

“Having sat back here and watched men commit suicide, mutilate themselves, try to overdose on pills and slowly lose their minds,” Hope wrote to lawyers, “I said to myself that I was going to try to make a positive change in the way we are housed and treated if it was the last thing I did.” https://nyti.ms/3Bk8Cc0

NYTIMES.COM
27 Years in Solitary Confinement, Then Another Plea for Help in Texas

Modern Love: “In short, I was fed up with white people. So one afternoon, I wrote a half-crazed manifesto on my Facebook page. Specifically, I railed against a white society that clearly didn’t see me as white but insisted on rejecting my Blackness because of my appearance (fair-skinned) and upbringing (middle class).
White people had called me ‘not Black’ for liking Taylor Swift, told me they were ‘more Black than me’ because they grew up in a predominantly Black neighborhood (or had an especially dark tan), and fetishized my ‘exoticness’ and ethnic ambiguity. I ended my ramblings with the call for applicants.
I clicked ‘post’ without thinking. To my amazement, the likes and comments started pouring in. Black people saying that they’d had similar experiences. White allies thanking me and promising to ‘do the work.’ I felt so vindicated.”

"I have had the same woman come once a week to clean my house for the past 10 years. She is a one-woman operation, so there is no one else to come in her place. I realize not having someone come to clean your house is not the world’s biggest tragedy, but it does leave me in the lurch with either cleaning projects left undone or a scramble to get done things I had not planned on having to do. I don't believe she is lying to me about feeling unwell. My granddaughter recently moved from her city apartment to our small town. She was having financial problems, and my husband and I decided to buy a small historic hotel in the hope that she could turn it into an artists’ retreat. She had always told us that it was one of her dreams.

In preparation for the move, my granddaughter brought her dog to stay for a week while she and her mother went back to finish packing. My granddaughter bought an Akita puppy during the Covid lockdown, and it became very attached to her. We learned that she had not tried to train or socialize it. We built a special kennel for it because it could not be put in the existing kennel with my daughter’s two dogs; they got into a fight on a previous visit. The first special kennel we built was only four feet tall, and the dog jumped out. So we built a new kennel with six-foot-tall panels. The dog chewed through the wire mesh and escaped. The next day, when my daughter, grandson and granddaughter decided to take all the dogs for a run, the dogs got in a fight. My grandson was bitten while trying to separate them and required medical attention.

Because my granddaughter needed to leave the dog while she and her mother returned home to pack, she decided to board it. The first night, the dog escaped and caused some destruction. Then it escaped again and did more damage. The kennel owner told my granddaughter that someone would have to come and pick up the dog. My husband and I had to drive an hour to get the dog. We constructed a secure pen with a roof so it could not escape. But it did, and then it got trapped in a room in the hotel we bought. It destroyed the curtains, the blinds, the bedding and an air-conditioner, and clawed the door and door frame, before crawling out a second-story window onto a roof and sliding off. The dog wound up at our daughter’s house a block away. I was upset and confronted my granddaughter upon her return. I said I did not want the dog in the house anymore.

My husband has worked with dog breeders. He says it would not be safe to allow the dog to stay, because if it escaped and injured someone, we could be liable. The dog growled at a neighbor who tried to catch it during one of its escapes. There are several Akita rescue groups in the area, and my husband wants my granddaughter to give the dog up. But she won’t, fearful that it might be euthanized.

My granddaughter says she can’t stay without her dog, and her mother says that we are responsible for all of this turmoil because we changed the rules and that we should compromise. My daughter insists that the dog is just very attached to my granddaughter and is not vicious, and says that I just don’t like the dog. It’s true that it has growled at me, and I am afraid of it. What do you think?

NYTIMES.COM
Can We Make Our Granddaughter Give Up Her Scary Dog?

Crissy Perham had never spoken publicly about her choice. In 31 years, Perham, a three-time Olympic medalist, told only a handful of people what it was like to be pregnant as a struggling college sophomore and decide to have an abortion. She kept quiet about how it helped pave the way for a swimming career and the success she experienced once it was over. But now, she said, speaking up is a must. "I’m 51, at the point where I shouldn’t be embarrassed about the decision I made for my reproductive health," Perham our columnist last week. “I recently joined a fast-growing health care company. I referred a candidate I worked with years ago, also a friend, who was a good match for an open position. My friend was offered the job, but I later learned that she intends to keep the full-time position she currently occupies while signing on for a full-time position at my company. Because each company allows for some remote work, she feels that she’ll be able to balance time for each. This arrangement is clearly against company policy, which requires, among other things, disclosure and approval of all other employment. My friend intends to keep her plans a secret from both companies.

When I made the referral, I had no reason to believe my friend would behave in this manner, and she remains undeterred despite my advice. I’m worried about the potential fallout for her and also that my reputation in the company could be tarnished if her deception comes to light. Now that I’m aware of her plans, should I warn my employer?”

"When I was a child in Catholic school, the nuns never tired of telling us how lucky we were. Of course we were lucky in the obvious ways that should never be taken for granted — lucky for our health, our food, our families, lucky to be able to go to school — but in the face of real disaster, our luck escalated dramatically.

At 9, when I came back to school after a car accident, they tallied up my good fortune: a broken nose, a broken wrist, my lip stitched back together, shards of glass still pushing out of my skull — it could have been so much worse! My sister was worse, she was still in the hospital. She would be there for awhile, resting between the white sheets of her astonishing luck. She should have been dead, and she wasn’t.

At the time, I thought the nuns were idiots. They simply refused to see how we suffered. But now — 48 years later — I think, man, were we lucky."

NYTIMES.COM
Sometimes the Luck Is in the Fall

In his mind, Michael Regan should have been down there. He should have had the guts.

A longtime New York City employee who became first deputy fire commissioner after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, Regan coordinated scores of funerals and memorial services and helped hundreds of shattered families. Still, he could not shake the guilt. He should have been there, down at the World Trade Center.

After a couple of months, he finally shared his remorse with a stunned Fire Department colleague, who told him that he had been there. He had helped transport the bodies of the first deputy fire commissioner, Bill Feehan, and the chief of department, Peter Ganci, to the morgue on First Avenue.

Don’t you remember?

Looking back, Regan said his mental block must have been a way to cope with the instant loss of thousands, including many close friends. “It was a safety mechanism,” he said. “I saw horrible things that day, and I didn’t want to think about those things.”

NYTIMES.COM
What Does It Mean to ‘Never Forget’?

Sofia LaRocca and Beau Maier were conservative spies posing as Democrats, who insinuated themselves into the fabric of progressive movements in the West. Using large campaign donations and cover stories, the operatives — veterans of the group Project Veritas — aimed to gather dirt that could sabotage the reputations of people and organizations in Wyoming and at least two other states, Colorado and Arizona. They set out to take on perceived threats to an agenda backed by Donald Trump, infiltrating the left, aiming to manipulate several states' politics — and ultimately tried to reshape the U.S. electoral map.

At 17, Juliane Diller was the sole survivor of a plane crash in the Amazon, waking up in the jungle on Christmas morning, 1971. 50 years later, she still returns to run Panguana, a research station in Peru founded by her parents. Dr. Diller remembers watching lightning strike the plane’s wing. She remembers the aircraft nose-diving and her mother saying, evenly, “Now it’s all over.” She remembers people weeping and screaming. And she remembers the thundering silence that followed.

She fell nearly two miles. Her row of seats is thought to have landed in dense foliage, cushioning the impact. Miraculously, her injuries were relatively minor. In shock, with a concussion and a small bag of candy, she soldiered on through the jungle. https://nyti.ms/3qeGmSz

At the age of 89, Opal Lee walked from her home in Fort Worth to Washington, D.C., in an effort to get Juneteenth named a national holiday. She traveled two and a half miles each day to symbolize the two and a half years that Black Texans waited between when Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation, on Jan. 1, 1863, abolishing slavery, and the day that message arrived in Galveston, where Black people were still enslaved, on June 19, 1865. "None of us are free till we’re all free," she said.

Now, at 94, her vision has become a reality. https://nyti.ms/3gCWbiX

The U.S. economy added 1.4 million jobs last month, as people who were furloughed earlier in the pandemic were brought back to work. But the pace of hiring was far slower than in the spring, and there are still millions who are out of work. Much of the job gains came from the hiring of close to 240,000 temporary workers for the 2020 census, most of whom will be laid off when census canvassing ends later this month.

The unemployment rate fell to 8.4% percent — lower than the peak of the Great Recession. But the number of jobs in the U.S. is still 11 million jobs below its pre-pandemic level.

She was a gold-medal-winning Paralympic athlete, a celebrity at home in Belgium and abroad. And she wanted to die. Marieke Vervoort lived in agonizing, unrelenting pain, battling a degenerative muscle disease that had been with her since her teenage years. 11 years ago, she obtained the paperwork to end her own life under Belgium's liberal laws for doctor-assisted suicide. “Because of those papers,” Marieke said, “I started to live again.” Andrew Keh and Lynsey Addario spent 3 years chronicling how she came to end her life as she suffered from the disease. What they saw was a top athlete taking control of her own destiny in an extraordinary fashion. “I want to die,” she told them in 2018. “I pray to die. But it’s so hard to say, ‘This is the day I want to go.’ Choosing a day is already dying a little bit.”

Read the story of her life, and how she eventually chose to end it. https://nyti.ms/38bQvpR

Frank Bruni
September 11, 2018 at 12:46 PM ·

Around noon N.Y.C. time every Wednesday, starting tomorrow, The Times will send anyone who has signed up for it a new weekly newsletter that I'm doing. It goes straight to your inbox. It's a more informal collection of commentary and observations that go beyond my columns. It's free. And I hope it will even be fun. If you want to give it a try, and I hope you do, subscribe here, nytimes.com/BruniLetter. You can unsubscribe at any time. If you think others in your universe would be interested in it, please share the sign-up link with them via social media, traditional email, whatever. And a big thanks simply for considering this and reading this far. And happy autumn!

President Trump has faced immense political pressure to end the separation of migrant families at the border. But the president’s executive order does nothing to address the plight of the more than 2,300 children who have already been separated from their parents under the president’s “zero tolerance” policy.

President Trump's "zero tolerance" policy to separate migrant children from their families has sparked massive controversy and bipartisan condemnation. To many, the policy, which disproportionately affects Latin American migrants, is the latest example of the United States' long history of racist immigration policies. We're joined by Erika Lee, the director of the Immigration History Research Center at the University of Minnesota, Allen Orr, an immigration lawyer, and Carly Goodman, historian and the communications analyst and Mellon/ACLS public fellow at American Friends Service Committee, for a conversation about U.S. immigration policy and how we got here. John Eligon and Rachel Swarns, NYT writers, will be moderating the discussion. If you have any questions or thoughts, leave them in the comments.
